title: 110_hr1695
content: The "Preventing Radicalism by Exploring and Vetting its Emergence as a National Threat (PREVENT) Act" may be cited as the short title. It establishes a National Commission on the Prevention of Radicalization. The National Commission on Radicalization and Terrorism is established in the legislative branch to examine and report on radicalization in the United States, including connections to non-US persons, radicalization in prison, lone wolf radicalization, gang activity, and internet use. It aims to build upon the work of other entities and avoid duplication. The National Commission on Radicalization and Terrorism will report findings and recommendations on countermeasures to radicalization in the United States, drawing from various sources including academic work, government studies, and foreign experiences. The National Commission on Radicalization and Terrorism consists of 20 members appointed by various officials, including the President, Senate majority leader, Senate minority leader, Speaker of the House, and others. The National Commission on Radicalization and Terrorism consists of 20 members appointed by various officials, including members appointed by different committees of the House of Representatives. The National Commission on Radicalization and Terrorism consists of 20 members appointed by various officials, including members appointed by different committees of the House of Representatives and the Senate. Members are appointed by the Chairman and ranking minority member of specific committees in both the House and Senate. The National Commission on Radicalization and Terrorism consists of 20 members appointed by various officials, including members appointed by different committees of the House of Representatives and the Senate. One member shall be appointed by the ranking minority member of the Judiciary Committee of the Senate. Individuals appointed to the Commission should be prominent United States citizens with national recognition and significant experience in professions such as law enforcement, armed services, sociology, psychology, technology, social networking, law, public administration, intelligence, corrections, and foreign affairs. All members must be appointed within 6 months of the enactment of this Act. The Commission shall meet and begin operations as soon as practicable. The National Commission on Radicalization and Terrorism, consisting of 20 members appointed by various officials, shall meet as soon as practicable. Subsequent meetings will be called by the Chairman or a majority of members. Eleven members constitute a quorum. Vacancies will not affect the Commission's powers and will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and administer oaths. The National Commission on Radicalization and Terrorism, with 20 appointed members, has the authority to hold hearings, receive evidence, and administer oaths. The Commission can also enter into contracts and obtain information from federal agencies for its duties. The National Commission on Radicalization and Terrorism can request information, suggestions, estimates, and statistics directly from federal agencies. Information handling must comply with relevant laws and regulations. The General Services Administration is required to provide assistance to the Commission. The National Commission on Radicalization and Terrorism can request information directly from federal agencies. General Services provides administrative support and other services on a reimbursable basis. Departments and agencies can also offer services, funds, facilities, staff, and support. The Commission can accept gifts, use postal services, and is not subject to the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The National Commission on Radicalization and Terrorism is not subject to the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The Commission holds public hearings and meetings, protects information, and appoints staff as necessary. The National Commission on Radicalization and Terrorism operates independently of certain federal regulations governing appointments and pay rates for its employees. The executive director and staff are considered federal employees for specific purposes under title 5 of the United States Code. The National Commission on Radicalization and Terrorism can appoint members without certain federal regulations applying. Federal employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and experts can be hired at specific rates. Emphasis is placed on security clearances for hiring employees and retaining contractors. The National Commission on Radicalization and Terrorism can appoint members without federal regulations applying. Members may receive compensation at a daily rate equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule. Travel expenses are allowed for members while performing services for the Commission. Government service expenses are allowed under section 5703(b) of title 5, United States Code. Federal agencies must provide security clearances to Commission members and staff. The Commission can submit interim reports to the President and Congress with findings and recommendations. A final report must be submitted within 24 months. The Commission will submit a final report to the President and Congress within 24 months of the enactment of the Act. The report will contain findings, conclusions, and recommendations agreed upon by a majority of Commission members. Public versions of the reports will be released. The Commission and its authorities will terminate 60 days after the final report is submitted. $9,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated for the Commission's activities, with funds available for a specified duration. The term "radicalization" is defined as adopting extremist beliefs and supporting violence for societal change. Amounts available to the Commission will remain until spent or the Commission terminates. The Secretary of Homeland Security will collaborate with CREATE to assess creating more incentives for private sector critical infrastructure stakeholders to share Protected Critical Infrastructure Information, including tax incentives, grant eligibility, and non-monetary incentives. Recommendations on the structure and thresholds of any incentive program will also be included in the evaluation.
